items.prompt: Which phrase is used to start an email asking for information?

items.explanation: 'I am writing to ask about...' is a standard way to introduce a request.

items.prompt: Which is more formal and polite?

Could you please send me the file?

items.prompt: What does 'I would like to know' mean?

items.prompt: Complete the request: 'Please ________ me know if the office is open.'
items.explanation: The correct phrase is 'Please let me know' (Por favor, házmelo saber).

items.prompt: Which modal verb is standard for requests between close colleagues?
items.explanation: 'Can you...?' is common and acceptable for colleagues with an informal relationship.

items.prompt: What follows 'Could you' in a question?
items.explanation: Modal verbs like 'Could' are followed by the base form of the verb.

items.prompt: How do you ask for a price list politely?

items.explanation: Using 'Could you...' makes the inquiry professional.

items.prompt: What is the meaning of 'Inquire'?
items.explanation: 'Inquire' (or enquire) means to ask for information.

items.title: Asking for Prices
items.text:
Subject: Inquiry about Office Supplies

Dear Sales Team,

I am writing to ask about your prices for printer paper and ink. Could you please send me a price list? I would also like to know if you have a discount for large orders.

Thank you for your help.

Best regards,

John Miller

questions.question: What is John asking for?
questions.explanation: He asks: 'Could you please send me a price list?'

questions.question: What else does he want to know?
questions.explanation: He says: 'I would also like to know if you have a discount'.

items.title: A Polite Request to a Colleague
items.text:
Hi Sarah,

Could you please help me with the monthly report? I need the sales data from June. Please let me know if you can send it today.

Thanks,

Mark

questions.question: What data does Mark need?
questions.explanation: He specifically asks for 'sales data from June'.

questions.question: When does he want it?
questions.explanation: He asks: 'if you can send it today'.

items.title: Formal and Informal Requests
items.text: In English, there are different ways to ask for things. To a friend, you can say 'Can you...?'. To a boss or a client, 'Could you...?' or 'I would like...' is better. It is important to use 'please' and 'thank you' to be professional.

questions.question: Which word is better for a boss?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Could you...?' is better for a boss.

questions.question: What two words are important for professionalism?
questions.explanation: The text mentions 'please' and 'thank you'.

items.title: Office Protocol
items.text: When you need something from another department, always send a formal request. Use a clear subject line like 'Request for [Item]'. State what you need and why. Always end with a polite closing.

questions.question: What should the subject line be?
questions.explanation: The text suggests 'Request for [Item]'.

questions.question: What should you state in the email?
questions.explanation: It says 'State what you need and why'.

items.title: Polite modals
items.text: 'Could you' is more polite than 'Can you'. We often use 'Could' when we ask for a favor or when we speak to someone we don't know well. 'Can' is more direct. In a professional email, 'Could' is always the safer choice.

questions.question: Which is more polite?
questions.explanation: The text says 'Could you' is more polite.

questions.question: When do we use 'Could'?
options: When we ask for a favor
questions.explanation: The text mentions both favors and people we don't know well.
